title: 113_s1773
content: The Act may be cited as the "Andrew Prior Act" or "Andrew's Law." It addresses the discharge of private student loans. Section 128(e) of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to include the discharge of private educational loans in the event of the borrower's death, defining terms like 'cosigner'. The amendment to Section 128(e) of the Truth in Lending Act includes provisions for the discharge of private educational loans in case of the borrower's death, defining terms like 'cosigner' and 'totally and permanently disabled'. The curr_chunk discusses the criteria for being considered disabled under the law, including the expectation of death or a continuous impairment lasting at least 60 months. The curr_chunk defines disability under title 38, United States Code as having a service-connected disability that is 100 percent disabling or being totally disabled based on an Individual Unemployability determination by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The curr_chunk discusses the discharge of private educational loans in the event of the borrower's death or total and permanent disability, relieving the estate or cosigner from repayment obligations. The Bureau is tasked with developing safeguards to prevent fraud and abuse in the loan discharge process. The Director may reinstate discharged loans under certain circumstances to protect the public interest. The Director of the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection may issue regulations necessary to carry out the Act.
